<p><strong>These days, </strong>you’re almost more likely to see the inside of a bank branch in an old movie than you are in real life. But take a look at your phone: there are probably at least two money apps on your home screen—maybe more. According to McKinsey research, this is just one sign of a <a href="https://www.mckinsey.com/~/media/mckinsey/industries/financial services/our insights/on the cusp of the next payments era future opportunities for banks/on-the-cusp-of-the-next-payments-era-future-opportunities-for-banks.pdf?shouldindex=false">new era in payments</a>. What’s one major development behind this shift? Short word, big concept: fintech.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-o-sm-right-span Image_mck-c-image__fhx5v"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c"><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-9 mdc-u-mt-3 Image_mck-c-image__description__nsDz3"><div><h5><strong>Get to know and directly engage with senior McKinsey experts on fintech</strong></h5>
<p><strong><a href="/our-people/max-flototto">Max Flötotto</a></strong> is a senior partner in McKinsey’s Munich office; <a href="https://www.mckinsey.com/our-people/brian-ledbetter"><strong>Brian Ledbetter</strong></a><strong><a href="/our-people/brian-ledbetter"> </a></strong> is a senior partner in the London office, where <strong><a href="/our-people/tunde-olanrewaju"> Tunde Olanrewaju</a></strong> is the managing partner of McKinsey’s UK, Ireland, and Israel offices; <strong><a href="/our-people/alexis-krivkovich"> Alexis Krivkovich</a></strong> and <a href="https://www.mckinsey.com/our-people/marie-claude-nadeau"><strong>Marie-Claude Nadeau</strong></a> are senior partners in the Bay Area office; and <strong><a href="/sitecore/service/notfound.aspx?item=web%3a%7be1f1f9ce-605d-4483-b05c-26f88b05792f%7d%40en">Eckart Windhagen</a></strong> is a senior partner in the Frankfurt office.</p></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Fintechs—short for financial technology—are <a href="/industries/financial-services/our-insights/fintechs-a-new-paradigm-of-growth">companies</a> that rely primarily on technology to conduct fundamental functions provided by financial services, affecting how users store, save, borrow, invest, move, pay, and protect money. Most fintechs were launched after 2000, have raised funding since 2010, and have not yet reached maturity. They make it not only possible but also easy to move money between accounts, people, countries, and organizations. There’s no typical fintech company: fintechs include start-ups, growth companies, banks, nonbank financial institutions, and even cross-sector firms. Examples range from peer-to-peer payment services such as Venmo and Zelle to automated portfolio managers and stock- or cryptocurrency-trading apps such as Robinhood and Coinbase.</p>
<p>Fintech came to prominence around 2010, primarily in the payments space. <a href="/industries/financial-services/our-insights/the-future-of-payments-is-frictionless-now-more-than-ever">Square</a>, for instance, which was founded in 2009, enabled small companies or sellers to accept credit cards via a mobile device. Today, fintech disruptions have expanded to every corner of finance—even areas once assumed to be safe from digital threat. Fintech is spreading fast: in the United States, for example, almost <a href="/industries/financial-services/our-insights/financial-services-unchained-the-ongoing-rise-of-open-financial-data">one in two consumers</a> in 2021 used a fintech product—primarily peer-to-peer payment products and nonbank money transfers. Fintechs also raised <a href="/industries/financial-services/our-insights/fintechs-a-new-paradigm-of-growth">record capital</a> in the second half of the 2010s: venture capital funding grew from $19.4 billion in 2015 to $33.3 billion in 2020.</p>
<p>But recently, the <a href="/industries/financial-services/our-insights/the-2023-mckinsey-global-payments-report">luster has worn off a bit</a>: in 2022, a market correction caused a slowdown in fintech’s explosive growth momentum. As a result, fintechs have had to adjust to lower valuations and decreased willingness on the part of venture capital firms to fund companies with low margins. Rather than sprinting toward the hockey stick of old, fintechs today are focused on <a href="/industries/financial-services/our-insights/fintechs-a-new-paradigm-of-growth">sustainable, profitable growth</a>. Banks, in response, have seized the opportunity, developing their own fintech-informed digital products and services. In the future, competition for client deposits and balances will likely intensify.</p>
<p>But before we look into the future, let’s first explore the past and present. What is fintech, what kinds of convenience does it offer, and where in the world is it being used? Read on to find out.</p>
<p><em>Learn more about McKinsey’s <a href="/industries/financial-services/how-we-help-clients">Financial Services Practice</a>.</em></p>
<h2>Where is the banking industry in its digitization journey?</h2>
<!-- -->
<p>Banking is in its second era of digitization, according to McKinsey senior partner <a href="/our-people/brian-ledbetter">Brian Ledbetter</a>. Traditionally, banks were anchored on a customer service arrangement that relied on branches and call centers. He says, “If you needed something, you’d either ring on the phone or go into the branch and get it done. Then, with the advent of smartphones, we discovered that mobile and digital technology was the primary way to engage with customers. . . . And so we had a boom in apps and automated journeys, which banks hooked up to their existing systems.”</p>
<p>This has led to a problem of technical debt: When banks set up this first phase of digitization, they did so with the technology they had at the time. Over time, these older systems have become obsolete. This created an opportunity for more agile fintech companies to disrupt business as usual, offering customers less clunky, more convenient ways of doing business. Today, <a href="/industries/financial-services/our-insights/banks-core-technology-conundrum-reaches-an-inflection-point">banks are at an upgrade point</a> for both the front and back ends. And their institutional capacity may be a benefit when it comes to adopting and deploying solutions based on <a href="/industries/financial-services/our-insights/been-there-doing-that-how-corporate-and-investment-banks-are-tackling-gen-ai">rapidly advancing new technologies</a>.</p>
<h2>Which three themes will shape the next chapter of fintech growth?</h2>
<p>According to our research, <a href="/industries/financial-services/our-insights/fintechs-a-new-paradigm-of-growth">three trends</a> will shape the next phase of fintech growth. First, fintechs will continue to benefit from the radical digital transformation of the banking industry and e-commerce growth around the world, particularly in developing countries. About 73 percent of the world’s interactions with banks now take place through digital channels. B2B firms are also demanding more fintech solutions than ever. To capitalize on the demand, fintechs will need to keep up with evolving regulations and ensure they have adequate resources to comply.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-4 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-5 Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__image___2Gc4"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture"><img alt="Circular, white maze filled with white semicircles." src="/~/media/mckinsey/featured%20insights/mckinsey%20explainers/mckinseyexplainers-flat-thumb-1536x1536.jpg?cq=50&mh=145&car=16:9&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-8 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-7"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Looking for direct answers to other complex questions?</div></h3></div></header><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c mck-c-disruptor1up__content Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__content--links__VV4lE mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/featured-insights/mckinsey-explainers" class="mdc-c-link-cta___NBQVi_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Explore the full McKinsey Explainers series</span><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mck-link-arrow-right-icon"></span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p>Second, despite short-term pressures, fintechs still have room to achieve further growth in an expanding financial-services ecosystem. McKinsey estimates that fintechs will grow at roughly three times the overall banking industry’s growth rate between 2022 and 2028. Emerging markets will fuel much of this growth, particularly in Africa, Asia–Pacific (excluding China), Latin America, and the Middle East.</p>
<p>Finally, some fintechs are proving more resilient during the current market correction than others. Companies in the growth stage (series C and beyond) showed the highest sensitivity to 2022’s downturn. Fintechs in the early and pre-seed stages were more resilient. Funding for B2B fintechs was more resilient than that for B2C ones. Banking as a service (BaaS) and embedded finance, and small and medium-size enterprises (SMEs) and corporate value-added services were the verticals least affected by the downturn.</p>
<p><em><em>Learn more about McKinsey’s <a href="/industries/financial-services/how-we-help-clients">Financial Services Practice</a>.</em></em></p>
<h2>Which technologies are shaping the future of fintech?</h2>
<p>Over the next few years, we predict that the following <a href="https://www.mckinsey.com/cn/our-insights/our-insights/seven-technologies-shaping-the-future-of-fintech">seven technologies</a> will advance fintech development while shaping the competitive landscape of finance:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Artificial intelligence (AI) will propel massive value creation</em>. Banks and other financial institutions are poised to adopt an <a href="/featured-insights/mckinsey-explainers/what-is-ai">AI</a>-first mindset that will better prepare them to fend off expanding technology firms. McKinsey estimates that generative AI technologies alone may add <a href="/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/the-economic-potential-of-generative-ai-the-next-productivity-frontier">up to $4.4 trillion annually</a> to the global economy.</li>
    <li><em>Blockchain</em>. <em><a href="/featured-insights/mckinsey-explainers/what-is-blockchain">Blockchain</a></em> will disrupt established financial protocols by allowing the storage of financial transactions in multiple places at once. Technologies such as smart contracts, zero-knowledge proof (a way of proving you have a piece of information without revealing what the information is), and distributed data storage and exchange—essential to existing fintech innovations such as digital wallets, digital assets, decentralized finance, and nonfungible tokens—will continue to play a prominent role.</li>
    <li><em>Cloud computing</em>. McKinsey research indicates that by 2030, cloud technology will account for EBITDA (earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortization) in excess of $1 trillion across the world’s top 500 companies. For financial-services companies, <a href="/featured-insights/mckinsey-explainers/what-is-cloud-computing">cloud computing</a> will increase efficiency and lower costs.</li>
    <li><em>The Internet of Things (IoT)</em>. <a href="/featured-insights/mckinsey-explainers/what-is-the-internet-of-things">IoT</a> applications for the finance industry include perception and smart sensor systems, wireless communication networks, and application and operations support.</li>
    <li><em>Open-source software, serverless architecture, and software as a service (SaaS)</em>. These three technologies have become must-haves for technology companies and traditional financial institutions launching new fintech businesses. They enable increased speed and scalability, both critical for new businesses competing in the winner-takes-all digital economy.</li>
    <li><em>No- and low-code development platforms</em>. These allow programmers and general users to develop applications through graphical user interfaces and configurations (such as drag-and-drop) instead of traditional computer programming.</li>
    <li><em>Hyper-automation</em>. Hyper-automation is the use of AI, deep learning, event-based software, and other technologies and tools to improve <a href="/featured-insights/mckinsey-explainers/what-is-decision-making">decision-making</a> efficiency and work automation.</li>
</ul>
<h2>How can fintechs shift toward sustainable growth?</h2>
<p>Fintechs today are operating in a new environment. They can no longer afford to focus on growth at any cost. Given new liquidity constraints, fintechs are emphasizing profitability, not just growth in customer adoption numbers or total revenues. In 2019, McKinsey conducted a study of the growth patterns and performance of the world’s 5,000 largest public companies over the preceding 15 years. Based on our analysis, we expect <a href="/industries/financial-services/our-insights/fintechs-a-new-paradigm-of-growth">four pathways</a> to deliver the most impact for fintechs:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Cost discipline</em>. Control costs to withstand the new funding environment while remaining flexible, nimble, and compliant.</li>
    <li><em>Measured growth based on a stable core</em>. Ensure there is a strong and stable core business with a targeted and proven market fit before expanding.</li>
    <li><em>Programmatic M&A</em>. Pursue M&A strategically and establish mutually beneficial partnerships based on programmatic strategy rooted in value sharing (with incumbents and other fintechs).</li>
    <li><em>Keep the culture alive</em>. Maintain the <a href="/featured-insights/mckinsey-explainers/what-is-agile">agility</a>, <a href="/featured-insights/mckinsey-explainers/what-is-innovation">innovation</a>, and culture that have propelled disruption so far.</li>
</ul>
<p><em><em>Learn more about McKinsey’s <a href="/industries/financial-services/how-we-help-clients">Financial Services Practice</a>.</em></em></p>
<h2>What is open financial data?</h2>
<p>Financial data is pretty self-explanatory. It’s records of what we spend, save, and borrow, from mortgage payments to what we paid for this morning’s latte. In the past, banks have been the keepers of our financial data, and the idea of sharing it with anyone probably made us a little uncomfortable. Now, some of that data is being shared with third parties. This is a trend called <a href="/industries/financial-services/our-insights/financial-services-unchained-the-ongoing-rise-of-open-financial-data">open financial data</a> or open banking.</p>
<p>Let’s make one thing clear: none of this happens without consumer consent. But when consumers do consent, they allow a new and growing set of actors—both financial and nonfinancial—to access their accounts and data to offer new products and services based on what they might need. This movement is still in its infancy but has <a href="/industries/financial-services/our-insights/financial-services-unchained-the-ongoing-rise-of-open-financial-data">big potential</a> to reshape our bank accounts, credit cards, payments, mortgages, loans, and even insurance policies.</p>
<p>The adoption of new digital-banking habits, in part as a result of fintech disruptions, appears to have accelerated open banking.</p>
<h2>What can incumbents do to prevent disruption from fintechs?</h2>
<p>Fintechs have successfully highlighted existing financial institutions’ weaknesses—in digital user experiences as well as in operational efficiency. It almost doesn’t matter how much market share fintechs take from incumbents when they have so successfully <a href="/industries/financial-services/our-insights/banking-matters/seven-ways-for-financial-institutions-to-react-to-financial-technology-companies">recast customer expectations</a>. At this point, it’s imperative for incumbents to transform to meet the new reality informed by fintechs. Here are seven actions for incumbents to consider:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Buy a fintech</em>, whether for its traction, technology, or talent. But success depends on post-acquisition integration.</li>
    <li><em>Partner with a fintech</em> to induce faster time to market and cost-efficient implementation.</li>
    <li><em>Invest in fintechs</em> to hedge against some of the potential threat of disruption.</li>
    <li><em>Transform to become more like a fintech</em>. <a href="/featured-insights/mckinsey-explainers/what-is-digital-transformation">Transformation</a> is necessary to compete with outside threats, fintech or otherwise.</li>
    <li><em>Build an internal fintech</em>. Increasingly, incumbents are building their own internal fintechs to self-disrupt areas of their business before others can disrupt them.</li>
    <li><em>Serve the fintechs</em>. A few financial institutions might find competitive advantage in BaaS, serving fintechs as well as retailers, telcos, and more.</li>
    <li><em>Ignore fintechs</em>. Ignoring competition is rarely the right choice, but some incumbents are built behind regulatory moats that are difficult to disrupt.</li>
</ul>
<p>The right answer is probably a combination of the above, implemented after careful planning.</p>
<p><em><em>Learn more about McKinsey’s <a href="/industries/financial-services/how-we-help-clients">Financial Services Practice</a>.</em></em></p>
<h2>How is fintech changing the financial landscape of Africa?</h2>
<p>Kenya has one of the highest levels of fintech penetration in the world, propelled largely by the explosive success of one fintech: <a href="/industries/financial-services/our-insights/driven-by-purpose-15-years-of-m-pesas-evolution">M-Pesa</a>. Launched in 2007, M-Pesa made it easier for Kenyans—and later, people in other countries—to use their mobile phones to reliably and quickly pay one another. It was quickly adopted by most Kenyans.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2cb14f98-b92d-45ab-9045-9ad74b5757f2"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2cb14f98-b92d-45ab-9045-9ad74b5757f2" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">  William Jack and Tavneet Suri, “The long-run poverty and gender impacts of mobile money,” <em>Science</em>, December 2016, Volume 354, Number 6,317.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Between 2020 and 2021, the number of tech start-ups in Africa tripled to about <a href="/industries/financial-services/our-insights/fintech-in-africa-the-end-of-the-beginning">5,200 companies</a>—and just under half of these are fintechs. Cash is used in about 90 percent of transactions in Africa, which means there is huge room for growth. If the sector overall can reach similar levels of penetration to those seen in Kenya, we’ve estimated that African fintech revenues could reach <a href="/industries/financial-services/our-insights/fintech-in-africa-the-end-of-the-beginning">eight times</a> their 2022 value by 2025.</p>
<p>Looking ahead, we anticipate that the growth opportunity in African fintech will likely be concentrated in 11 key markets: Cameroon, Côte d’Ivoire, Egypt, Ghana, Kenya, Morocco, <a href="/featured-insights/middle-east-and-africa/harnessing-nigerias-fintech-potential">Nigeria</a>, Senegal, South Africa (home to the continent’s most mature banking system), Tanzania, and Uganda. Together, these markets account for 70 percent of Africa’s GDP and half its population.</p>
<p>Here are four challenges emerging African fintechs may face:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Reaching scale and profitability</em>. The total addressable market (that is, the number of viable customers) for African fintechs may be limited by infrastructure constraints, including weak mobile and internet penetration, lack of internet coverage, and limited payment rails (the underlying infrastructure that facilitates transactions). Lower disposable income and lower customer loyalty may also make it harder for fintechs to scale.</li>
    <li><em>Navigating an uncertain regulatory environment</em>. Different countries evolve regulations at different paces. Generally, complex and variable regulations make it difficult for fintechs to ensure business continuity and compliance across markets.</li>
    <li><em>Managing scarcity</em>. Funding is slowing down for African fintechs after a record-breaking 2021. But fintechs can’t afford to slow down their progress, especially as incumbents begin catching up. This suggests African fintechs will have to tighten their belts to adjust to a new venture funding reality.</li>
    <li><em>Building robust corporate-governance foundations</em>. In a regulatory, socioeconomic, and political environment that can be uncertain and fragmented, a strong corporate-governance structure can provide stability, clarity, and direction, especially in times of difficulty. Strong corporate governance includes strong culture building, productive stakeholder engagement, and a clear talent strategy to build the organization’s capabilities.
    <p> </p>
    </li>
</ul>
<p>We don’t predict the path ahead to be smooth. But if stakeholders can work together to build on the momentum of recent years, the prospects for African fintechs are good.</p>
<h2>What’s the state of fintech in Europe?</h2>
<p>Fintech in Europe was <a href="/industries/financial-services/our-insights/detour-an-altered-path-to-profit-for-european-fintechs">hit hard by COVID-19</a> and the resulting economic uncertainty. But in the long term, fintechs continue to gain in strength and relevance for customers and the economy. In each of the seven largest European economies, as measured by GDP, at least one fintech ranks among the <a href="/industries/financial-services/our-insights/europes-fintech-opportunity">top five banking institutions</a>.</p>
<p>But fintech has not progressed in each European market at the same speed. There’s a wide divergence of maturity and performance among countries, with a substantial gap between the top one-third and the rest. Two countries in particular stand out for their superior fintech ecosystem performance: Sweden and the United Kingdom. If fintech ecosystems in all European countries were to perform as well as the best in the region, the upside would be substantial: the number of fintech jobs would grow to more than 364,000, the volume of funding would more than double to almost €150 billion, and valuations would balloon to almost €1 trillion.</p>
<p>Here are the ways in which fintechs can <a href="/industries/financial-services/our-insights/europes-fintech-opportunity">benefit European stakeholders</a>:</p>
<ul>
    <li>The appeal of fintechs to European customers is that they offer superior service at lower costs. International transfers, for example, can cost just 10 percent of the rates charged by traditional banking service institutions.</li>
    <li>Fintechs are a catalyst for disruptive innovation and growth in the financial ecosystem as a whole. They are typically more agile and quicker than incumbents, which means they are able to launch new products and services much faster (average time to market for fintechs is as little as two months, compared with 12 months for incumbents).</li>
    <li>Fintechs are an important source of potential growth for the overall economy. As of 2022, fintechs have created approximately 134,000 jobs across Europe and represent a total valuation of almost €430 billion. That’s more than the combined market capitalization of Europe’s seven largest listed banks.</li>
</ul>
<p>For the European financial system to achieve the potential made possible by fintech, stakeholders such as public institutions, incumbents, and fintech upstarts will need to combine their strengths by setting up appropriate enabling structures and mechanisms.</p>
<p><em><em>Learn more about McKinsey’s <a href="/industries/financial-services/how-we-help-clients">Financial Services Practice</a>.</em></em></p>
<h2>What’s the future of fintech in the Middle East, North Africa, and Pakistan?</h2>
<p>Fintech has boomed in the Middle East, North Africa, and Pakistan (MENAP) in recent years: investor backing increased by <a href="/industries/financial-services/our-insights/fintech-in-menap-a-solid-foundation-for-growth">around 36 percent annually</a> from 2017 to 2022.</p>
<p>Here are five types of fintech companies in MENAP:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Homegrown fintech start-ups</em>. Local fintech start-ups are addressing not only payments, lending, insurtech, and investments but also additional consumer and business needs such as home buying, payment apps and wallets, and merchant payment solutions.</li>
    <li><em>International fintech firms</em>. Established international fintech firms have launched in MENAP, stimulating competition and helping promote customer adoption.</li>
    <li><em>Banks</em>. Leading banking incumbents have moved quickly to offer digital-only offerings. These include Weyay Bank, a digital, youth-oriented bank by National Bank of Kuwait; Liv, a digital lifestyle banking app from Emirates National Bank of Dubai; and others.</li>
    <li><em>Other nonbank financial institutions</em>. Established payment processors, exchanges, remittance services, and other traditional infrastructure providers have launched mobile apps and digital portals. In some cases, they have partnered with fintech start-ups.</li>
    <li><em>Cross-sector fintech firms</em>. Large companies with leading market share, especially in telecommunications, have progressed from mobile cash to broader offerings such as mobile wallets, mobile payments, and branchless banking services.</li>
</ul>
<p>While 2022 brought with it a global drop in fintech valuations, we believe the market in MENAP is likely to continue growing. By 2025, we estimate that fintech revenue in MENAP could be up to $4.5 billion.</p>
<p>Realizing this potential is another story. For fintechs to continue to expand their roles in the daily lives of consumers and businesses in MENAP, they’ll need to invest capital, work with regulators, and cultivate talent and partnerships.</p>
<p><em>Learn more about McKinsey’s <em><em><a href="/industries/financial-services/how-we-help-clients">Financial Services Practice</a></em></em>. And check out <a href="https://www.mckinsey.com/careers/old-search-jobs#?query=fintech#?">fintech-related job opportunities</a> if you’re interested in working at McKinsey.</em></p>

why financial technology companies have become critical components of the global economy."},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2024-01-16T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[image 1]]\n[[audio 1]]\n[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThese days, \u003c/strong\u003eyou\u0026rsquo;re almost more likely to see the inside of a bank branch in an old movie than you are in real life. But take a look at your phone: there are probably at least two money apps on your home screen\u0026mdash;maybe more. According to McKinsey research, this is just one sign of a \u003ca href=\"https://www.mckinsey.com/~/media/mckinsey/industries/financial services/our insights/on the cusp of the next payments era future opportunities for banks/on-the-cusp-of-the-next-payments-era-future-opportunities-for-banks.pdf?shouldindex=false\"\u003enew era in payments\u003c/a\u003e. What\u0026rsquo;s one major development behind this shift? Short word, big concept: fintech.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[image authors]]\n\u003cp\u003eFintechs\u0026mdash;short for financial technology\u0026mdash;are \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/fintechs-a-new-paradigm-of-growth\"\u003ecompanies\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;that rely primarily on technology to conduct fundamental functions provided by financial services, affecting how users store, save, borrow, invest, move, pay, and protect money. Most fintechs were launched after 2000, have raised funding since 2010, and have not yet reached maturity. They make it not only possible but also easy to move money between accounts, people, countries, and organizations. There\u0026rsquo;s no typical fintech company: fintechs include start-ups, growth companies, banks, nonbank financial institutions, and even cross-sector firms. Examples range from peer-to-peer payment services such as Venmo and Zelle to automated portfolio managers and stock- or cryptocurrency-trading apps such as Robinhood and Coinbase.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFintech came to prominence around 2010, primarily in the payments space. \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/the-future-of-payments-is-frictionless-now-more-than-ever\"\u003eSquare\u003c/a\u003e, for instance, which was founded in 2009, enabled small companies or sellers to accept credit cards via a mobile device. Today, fintech disruptions have expanded to every corner of finance\u0026mdash;even areas once assumed to be safe from digital threat. Fintech is spreading fast: in the United States, for example, almost \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/financial-services-unchained-the-ongoing-rise-of-open-financial-data\"\u003eone in two consumers\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;in 2021 used a fintech product\u0026mdash;primarily peer-to-peer payment products and nonbank money transfers. Fintechs also raised \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/fintechs-a-new-paradigm-of-growth\"\u003erecord capital\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;in the second half of the 2010s: venture capital funding grew from $19.4 billion in 2015 to $33.3 billion in 2020.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut recently, the \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/the-2023-mckinsey-global-payments-report\"\u003eluster has worn off a bit\u003c/a\u003e: in 2022, a market correction caused a slowdown in fintech\u0026rsquo;s explosive growth momentum. As a result, fintechs have had to adjust to lower valuations and decreased willingness on the part of venture capital firms to fund companies with low margins. Rather than sprinting toward the hockey stick of old, fintechs today are focused on \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/fintechs-a-new-paradigm-of-growth\"\u003esustainable, profitable growth\u003c/a\u003e. Banks, in response, have seized the opportunity, developing their own fintech-informed digital products and services. In the future, competition for client deposits and balances will likely intensify.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut before we look into the future, let\u0026rsquo;s first explore the past and present. What is fintech, what kinds of convenience does it offer, and where in the world is it being used? Read on to find out.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eLearn more about McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/how-we-help-clients\"\u003eFinancial Services Practice\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eWhere is the banking industry in its digitization journey?\u003c/h2\u003e\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eBanking is in its second era of digitization, according to McKinsey senior partner \u003ca href=\"/our-people/brian-ledbetter\"\u003eBrian Ledbetter\u003c/a\u003e. Traditionally, banks were anchored on a customer service arrangement that relied on branches and call centers. He says, \u0026ldquo;If you needed something, you\u0026rsquo;d either ring on the phone or go into the branch and get it done. Then, with the advent of smartphones, we discovered that mobile and digital technology was the primary way to engage with customers. . . . And so we had a boom in apps and automated journeys, which banks hooked up to their existing systems.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis has led to a problem of technical debt: When banks set up this first phase of digitization, they did so with the technology they had at the time. Over time, these older systems have become obsolete. This created an opportunity for more agile fintech companies to disrupt business as usual, offering customers less clunky, more convenient ways of doing business. Today, \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/banks-core-technology-conundrum-reaches-an-inflection-point\"\u003ebanks are at an upgrade point\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;for both the front and back ends. And their institutional capacity may be a benefit when it comes to adopting and deploying solutions based on \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/been-there-doing-that-how-corporate-and-investment-banks-are-tackling-gen-ai\"\u003erapidly advancing new technologies\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eWhich three themes will shape the next chapter of fintech growth?\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAccording to our research, \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/fintechs-a-new-paradigm-of-growth\"\u003ethree trends\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;will shape the next phase of fintech growth. First, fintechs will continue to benefit from the radical digital transformation of the banking industry and e-commerce growth around the world, particularly in developing countries. About 73 percent of the world\u0026rsquo;s interactions with banks now take place through digital channels. B2B firms are also demanding more fintech solutions than ever. To capitalize on the demand, fintechs will need to keep up with evolving regulations and ensure they have adequate resources to comply.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Disruptor1up mckinseyexplainers]]\n\u003cp\u003eSecond, despite short-term pressures, fintechs still have room to achieve further growth in an expanding financial-services ecosystem. McKinsey estimates that fintechs will grow at roughly three times the overall banking industry\u0026rsquo;s growth rate between 2022 and 2028. Emerging markets will fuel much of this growth, particularly in Africa, Asia\u0026ndash;Pacific (excluding China), Latin America, and the Middle East.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFinally, some fintechs are proving more resilient during the current market correction than others. Companies in the growth stage (series C and beyond) showed the highest sensitivity to 2022\u0026rsquo;s downturn. Fintechs in the early and pre-seed stages were more resilient. Funding for B2B fintechs was more resilient than that for B2C ones. Banking as a service (BaaS) and embedded finance, and small and medium-size enterprises (SMEs) and corporate value-added services were the verticals least affected by the downturn.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cem\u003eLearn more about McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/how-we-help-clients\"\u003eFinancial Services Practice\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eWhich technologies are shaping the future of fintech?\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOver the next few years, we predict that the following \u003ca href=\"https://www.mckinsey.com/cn/our-insights/our-insights/seven-technologies-shaping-the-future-of-fintech\"\u003eseven technologies\u003c/a\u003e will advance fintech development while shaping the competitive landscape of finance:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eArtificial intelligence (AI) will propel massive value creation\u003c/em\u003e. Banks and other financial institutions are poised to adopt an \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-explainers/what-is-ai\"\u003eAI\u003c/a\u003e-first mindset that will better prepare them to fend off expanding technology firms. McKinsey estimates that generative AI technologies alone may add \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/the-economic-potential-of-generative-ai-the-next-productivity-frontier\"\u003eup to $4.4 trillion annually\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;to the global economy.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eBlockchain\u003c/em\u003e. \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-explainers/what-is-blockchain\"\u003eBlockchain\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;will disrupt established financial protocols by allowing the storage of financial transactions in multiple places at once. Technologies such as smart contracts, zero-knowledge proof (a way of proving you have a piece of information without revealing what the information is), and distributed data storage and exchange\u0026mdash;essential to existing fintech innovations such as digital wallets, digital assets, decentralized finance, and nonfungible tokens\u0026mdash;will continue to play a prominent role.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eCloud computing\u003c/em\u003e. McKinsey research indicates that by 2030, cloud technology will account for EBITDA (earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortization) in excess of $1 trillion across the world\u0026rsquo;s top 500 companies. For financial-services companies, \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-explainers/what-is-cloud-computing\"\u003ecloud computing\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;will increase efficiency and lower costs.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eThe Internet of Things (IoT)\u003c/em\u003e. \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-explainers/what-is-the-internet-of-things\"\u003eIoT\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;applications for the finance industry include perception and smart sensor systems, wireless communication networks, and application and operations support.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eOpen-source software, serverless architecture, and software as a service (SaaS)\u003c/em\u003e. These three technologies have become must-haves for technology companies and traditional financial institutions launching new fintech businesses. They enable increased speed and scalability, both critical for new businesses competing in the winner-takes-all digital economy.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eNo- and low-code development platforms\u003c/em\u003e. These allow programmers and general users to develop applications through graphical user interfaces and configurations (such as drag-and-drop) instead of traditional computer programming.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eHyper-automation\u003c/em\u003e. Hyper-automation is the use of AI, deep learning, event-based software, and other technologies and tools to improve \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-explainers/what-is-decision-making\"\u003edecision-making\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;efficiency and work automation.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eHow can fintechs shift toward sustainable growth?\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFintechs today are operating in a new environment. They can no longer afford to focus on growth at any cost. Given new liquidity constraints, fintechs are emphasizing profitability, not just growth in customer adoption numbers or total revenues. In 2019, McKinsey conducted a study of the growth patterns and performance of the world\u0026rsquo;s 5,000 largest public companies over the preceding 15 years. Based on our analysis, we expect \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/fintechs-a-new-paradigm-of-growth\"\u003efour pathways\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;to deliver the most impact for fintechs:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eCost discipline\u003c/em\u003e. Control costs to withstand the new funding environment while remaining flexible, nimble, and compliant.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eMeasured growth based on a stable core\u003c/em\u003e. Ensure there is a strong and stable core business with a targeted and proven market fit before expanding.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eProgrammatic M\u0026amp;A\u003c/em\u003e. Pursue M\u0026amp;A strategically and establish mutually beneficial partnerships based on programmatic strategy rooted in value sharing (with incumbents and other fintechs).\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eKeep the culture alive\u003c/em\u003e. Maintain the \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-explainers/what-is-agile\"\u003eagility\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-explainers/what-is-innovation\"\u003einnovation\u003c/a\u003e, and culture that have propelled disruption so far.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cem\u003eLearn more about McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/how-we-help-clients\"\u003eFinancial Services Practice\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eWhat is open financial data?\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFinancial data is pretty self-explanatory. It\u0026rsquo;s records of what we spend, save, and borrow, from mortgage payments to what we paid for this morning\u0026rsquo;s latte. In the past, banks have been the keepers of our financial data, and the idea of sharing it with anyone probably made us a little uncomfortable. Now, some of that data is being shared with third parties. This is a trend called \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/financial-services-unchained-the-ongoing-rise-of-open-financial-data\"\u003eopen financial data\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;or open banking.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet\u0026rsquo;s make one thing clear: none of this happens without consumer consent. But when consumers do consent, they allow a new and growing set of actors\u0026mdash;both financial and nonfinancial\u0026mdash;to access their accounts and data to offer new products and services based on what they might need. This movement is still in its infancy but has \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/financial-services-unchained-the-ongoing-rise-of-open-financial-data\"\u003ebig potential\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;to reshape our bank accounts, credit cards, payments, mortgages, loans, and even insurance policies.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe adoption of new digital-banking habits, in part as a result of fintech disruptions, appears to have accelerated open banking.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eWhat can incumbents do to prevent disruption from fintechs?\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFintechs have successfully highlighted existing financial institutions\u0026rsquo; weaknesses\u0026mdash;in digital user experiences as well as in operational efficiency. It almost doesn\u0026rsquo;t matter how much market share fintechs take from incumbents when they have so successfully \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/banking-matters/seven-ways-for-financial-institutions-to-react-to-financial-technology-companies\"\u003erecast customer expectations\u003c/a\u003e. At this point, it\u0026rsquo;s imperative for incumbents to transform to meet the new reality informed by fintechs. Here are seven actions for incumbents to consider:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eBuy a fintech\u003c/em\u003e, whether for its traction, technology, or talent. But success depends on post-acquisition integration.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003ePartner with a fintech\u003c/em\u003e to induce faster time to market and cost-efficient implementation.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eInvest in fintechs\u003c/em\u003e to hedge against some of the potential threat of disruption.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eTransform to become more like a fintech\u003c/em\u003e. \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-explainers/what-is-digital-transformation\"\u003eTransformation\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;is necessary to compete with outside threats, fintech or otherwise.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eBuild an internal fintech\u003c/em\u003e. Increasingly, incumbents are building their own internal fintechs to self-disrupt areas of their business before others can disrupt them.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eServe the fintechs\u003c/em\u003e. A few financial institutions might find competitive advantage in BaaS, serving fintechs as well as retailers, telcos, and more.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eIgnore fintechs\u003c/em\u003e. Ignoring competition is rarely the right choice, but some incumbents are built behind regulatory moats that are difficult to disrupt.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe right answer is probably a combination of the above, implemented after careful planning.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cem\u003eLearn more about McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/how-we-help-clients\"\u003eFinancial Services Practice\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eHow is fintech changing the financial landscape of Africa?\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eKenya has one of the highest levels of fintech penetration in the world, propelled largely by the explosive success of one fintech: \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/driven-by-purpose-15-years-of-m-pesas-evolution\"\u003eM-Pesa\u003c/a\u003e. Launched in 2007, M-Pesa made it easier for Kenyans\u0026mdash;and later, people in other countries\u0026mdash;to use their mobile phones to reliably and quickly pay one another. It was quickly adopted by most Kenyans.[[footnote 1]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBetween 2020 and 2021, the number of tech start-ups in Africa tripled to about \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/fintech-in-africa-the-end-of-the-beginning\"\u003e5,200 companies\u003c/a\u003e\u0026mdash;and just under half of these are fintechs. Cash is used in about 90 percent of transactions in Africa, which means there is huge room for growth. If the sector overall can reach similar levels of penetration to those seen in Kenya, we\u0026rsquo;ve estimated that African fintech revenues could reach \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/fintech-in-africa-the-end-of-the-beginning\"\u003eeight times\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;their 2022 value by 2025.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLooking ahead, we anticipate that the growth opportunity in African fintech will likely be concentrated in 11 key markets: Cameroon, C\u0026ocirc;te d\u0026rsquo;Ivoire, Egypt, Ghana, Kenya, Morocco, \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/middle-east-and-africa/harnessing-nigerias-fintech-potential\"\u003eNigeria\u003c/a\u003e, Senegal, South Africa (home to the continent\u0026rsquo;s most mature banking system), Tanzania, and Uganda. Together, these markets account for 70 percent of Africa\u0026rsquo;s GDP and half its population.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHere are four challenges emerging African fintechs may face:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eReaching scale and profitability\u003c/em\u003e. The total addressable market (that is, the number of viable customers) for African fintechs may be limited by infrastructure constraints, including weak mobile and internet penetration, lack of internet coverage, and limited payment rails (the underlying infrastructure that facilitates transactions). Lower disposable income and lower customer loyalty may also make it harder for fintechs to scale.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eNavigating an uncertain regulatory environment\u003c/em\u003e. Different countries evolve regulations at different paces. Generally, complex and variable regulations make it difficult for fintechs to ensure business continuity and compliance across markets.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eManaging scarcity\u003c/em\u003e. Funding is slowing down for African fintechs after a record-breaking 2021. But fintechs can\u0026rsquo;t afford to slow down their progress, especially as incumbents begin catching up. This suggests African fintechs will have to tighten their belts to adjust to a new venture funding reality.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eBuilding robust corporate-governance foundations\u003c/em\u003e. In a regulatory, socioeconomic, and political environment that can be uncertain and fragmented, a strong corporate-governance structure can provide stability, clarity, and direction, especially in times of difficulty. Strong corporate governance includes strong culture building, productive stakeholder engagement, and a clear talent strategy to build the organization\u0026rsquo;s capabilities.\n    \u003cp\u003e\u0026nbsp;\u003c/p\u003e\n    \u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe don\u0026rsquo;t predict the path ahead to be smooth. But if stakeholders can work together to build on the momentum of recent years, the prospects for African fintechs are good.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eWhat\u0026rsquo;s the state of fintech in Europe?\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFintech in Europe was \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/detour-an-altered-path-to-profit-for-european-fintechs\"\u003ehit hard by COVID-19\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;and the resulting economic uncertainty. But in the long term, fintechs continue to gain in strength and relevance for customers and the economy. In each of the seven largest European economies, as measured by GDP, at least one fintech ranks among the \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/europes-fintech-opportunity\"\u003etop five banking institutions\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut fintech has not progressed in each European market at the same speed. There\u0026rsquo;s a wide divergence of maturity and performance among countries, with a substantial gap between the top one-third and the rest. Two countries in particular stand out for their superior fintech ecosystem performance: Sweden and the United Kingdom. If fintech ecosystems in all European countries were to perform as well as the best in the region, the upside would be substantial: the number of fintech jobs would grow to more than 364,000, the volume of funding would more than double to almost \u0026euro;150 billion, and valuations would balloon to almost \u0026euro;1 trillion.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHere are the ways in which fintechs can \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/europes-fintech-opportunity\"\u003ebenefit European stakeholders\u003c/a\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eThe appeal of fintechs to European customers is that they offer superior service at lower costs. International transfers, for example, can cost just 10 percent of the rates charged by traditional banking service institutions.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eFintechs are a catalyst for disruptive innovation and growth in the financial ecosystem as a whole. They are typically more agile and quicker than incumbents, which means they are able to launch new products and services much faster (average time to market for fintechs is as little as two months, compared with 12 months for incumbents).\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eFintechs are an important source of potential growth for the overall economy. As of 2022, fintechs have created approximately 134,000 jobs across Europe and represent a total valuation of almost \u0026euro;430 billion. That\u0026rsquo;s more than the combined market capitalization of Europe\u0026rsquo;s seven largest listed banks.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor the European financial system to achieve the potential made possible by fintech, stakeholders such as public institutions, incumbents, and fintech upstarts will need to combine their strengths by setting up appropriate enabling structures and mechanisms.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cem\u003eLearn more about McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/how-we-help-clients\"\u003eFinancial Services Practice\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eWhat\u0026rsquo;s the future of fintech in the Middle East, North Africa, and Pakistan?\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFintech has boomed in the Middle East, North Africa, and Pakistan (MENAP) in recent years: investor backing increased by \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/fintech-in-menap-a-solid-foundation-for-growth\"\u003earound 36 percent annually\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;from 2017 to 2022.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHere are five types of fintech companies in MENAP:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eHomegrown fintech start-ups\u003c/em\u003e. Local fintech start-ups are addressing not only payments, lending, insurtech, and investments but also additional consumer and business needs such as home buying, payment apps and wallets, and merchant payment solutions.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eInternational fintech firms\u003c/em\u003e. Established international fintech firms have launched in MENAP, stimulating competition and helping promote customer adoption.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eBanks\u003c/em\u003e. Leading banking incumbents have moved quickly to offer digital-only offerings. These include Weyay Bank, a digital, youth-oriented bank by National Bank of Kuwait; Liv, a digital lifestyle banking app from Emirates National Bank of Dubai; and others.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eOther nonbank financial institutions\u003c/em\u003e. Established payment processors, exchanges, remittance services, and other traditional infrastructure providers have launched mobile apps and digital portals. In some cases, they have partnered with fintech start-ups.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eCross-sector fintech firms\u003c/em\u003e. Large companies with leading market share, especially in telecommunications, have progressed from mobile cash to broader offerings such as mobile wallets, mobile payments, and branchless banking services.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhile 2022 brought with it a global drop in fintech valuations, we believe the market in MENAP is likely to continue growing. By 2025, we estimate that fintech revenue in MENAP could be up to $4.5 billion.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRealizing this potential is another story. For fintechs to continue to expand their roles in the daily lives of consumers and businesses in MENAP, they\u0026rsquo;ll need to invest capital, work with regulators, and cultivate talent and partnerships.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eLearn more about McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s \u003cem\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/how-we-help-clients\"\u003eFinancial Services Practice\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/em\u003e. And check out \u003ca href=\"https://www.mckinsey.com/careers/old-search-jobs#?query=fintech#?\"\u003efintech-related job opportunities\u003c/a\u003e if you\u0026rsquo;re interested in working at McKinsey.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003ePop quiz\u003c/h2\u003e\n[[quiz 32]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eArticles referenced:\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/fintechs-a-new-paradigm-of-growth\"\u003eFintechs: A new paradigm of growth\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo;
